title: 103_hr3245
content: There is an increase in tax on ammunition. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to increase taxes on firearms and ammunition. Firearms are now taxable at 35 percent, while shells and cartridges are taxable at 11 percent. The effective date of this amendment is 30 days after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, a floor stocks tax is imposed on firearms held for sale by dealers before the tax-increase date. The floor stocks tax is imposed on firearms held by dealers before the tax-increase date. The amount of tax is determined by the difference between the tax that would have been imposed under the new amendment and the tax previously paid on the firearm. Dealers are liable for the tax and must pay accordingly. The tax imposed on firearms held by dealers before the tax-increase date must be paid before the close of a 6-month period. Definitions include the tax-increase date as the 1st day of the 1st calendar month after 30 days from the enactment of the Act, and 'firearm' is defined as any pistol, revolver, or other firearm. The floor stocks taxes imposed on firearms must be paid within 6 months. All relevant laws and penalties applicable to section 4181 taxes apply to floor stocks taxes. SEC. 2. HOSPITAL GUNSHOT COST RELIEF TRUST FUND. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish the Hospital Gunshot Cost Relief Trust Fund. The Hospital Gunshot Cost Relief Trust Fund is created in the Treasury of the United States, funded by additional firearms taxes to cover hospital costs related to gunshot injuries. The Hospital Gunshot Cost Relief Trust Fund is funded by additional firearms taxes imposed at a rate exceeding 10 percent for pistols, revolvers, and other firearms. Amounts in the fund are used to assist urban hospitals in covering medical expenses for gunshot victims without health insurance.
